item.title: Everything We Learned About Magic The Gathering Aetherdrift
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/tabletop/news/everything-we-learned-about-magic-gathering-aetherdrift

Magic The Gathering is off to the races with the new expansion, Aetherdrift, using the setting of an interplanar Grand Prix to bring together well-known characters and refresh lore on some less-seen planes and their inhabitants. Magic The Gathering Aetherdrift releases physically on February 14th.

Before it releases we got to sit down with members of the team behind Aetherdrift including Max McCall – Executive Producer, Miguel Lopez  – Worldbuilding Lead, Sarah Wassel  – Senior Art Director, and Lisa Hanson – Print Innovation Director. Through this call, we were treated to information about some of the different teams that would be competing in the Grand Prix, some unique mechanics to the set, and what kinds of new card treatments we'd be seeing.

Welcome To The Ghirapur Grand Prix!

There are 10 different racing teams from across the different planes that are being gathered to compete in the Ghirapur Grand Prix. Miguel Lopez took some time to explain to us just what that is.

"Aetherdrift focuses on an edition of a multi-day multi-planar combat stage race called the Ghirapur Grand Prix. This is a race put on by the plane of Avishkar. It's intended to be, on the one, a thrilling spectacle that is inspiring to watch and a statement to the multiverse of the new Avishkari government's ability to manage and coordinate multi-planar logistics."

The first Grand Prix has already happened off-screen, it's more chaotic and a test for the technology, and the second Grand Prix is the one that is the setting of Aetherdrift.

For the Avishkar this isn't just a chance to show off their power but also to connect with their neighboring planes to spread their "currency, food, language, and establish embassies."

Other planes involved in the Grand Prix include Amonket and Muraganda. While it will be a return to Amonket, slowly rebuilding itself after the Phyrexian Invasion, it will be the first deep dive into Muraganda "a place where magic and life is raw and young."

But what is the prize for such an impressive tournament? The Aetherspark, a Planeswalker spark suspended in a super-cooled aether solution.

The Mechanics Of Racing

The key mechanic that Aetherdrift is introducing is Speed. At the start of the game you'll start with no speed, by playing a card that has the Start your engines! Trait your speed will become 1.

You can then gain one speed per turn by causing your opponent to lose life. If you Start your engines! and then Lightning Bolt will get you to Speed 2, but another Lightning Bolt won't get you to Speed 3 on the same turn. Once you've reached Speed 4 you'll be at max speed and can't increase it any further.

Each of the cards that have the Start your engines! Trait also have a Trait that relates to an additional effect once max speed has been reached. An example given was Vnwxt, Verbose Host will let you draw two cards when you would normally only be able to draw one.

Another mechanic being introduced is Exhaust. This is a one-shot mechanic that does something powerful, that the player needs to know when to use to get the most effectiveness out of it. Exhaust can only be used once by a card, so if you see a card like Loot, The Pathfinder who has three powerful Exhaust abilities you'll only get to use one.

Interestingly, if a card has been returned to your hand and played again the Exhaust gets refreshed. This allows for some tricky wants to be able to refresh that and use these powerful abilities again.

"In general, you can only activate Exhaust abilities once per game… unless you're doing shenanigans" - Max McCall

The last new mechanic is Saddle. This allows Mount cards to be saddled by other creatures you control. Some of the Mounts that appear in this set aren't just mechanical vehicles but also beasts such as beast mounts. When cards are Saddled normally something extra-good happens.

The Ten Teams Of The Ghirapur Grand Prix

There are ten teams from across the planes that are competing in the Ghirapur Grand Prix. Each team doesn't just represent a plane or group but consists of two colors, this will help players find the right team for their playstyle. These teams are:

  1. Guidelight Voyagers (White / Blue) - A returning team that was accidentally formed during the first Grand Prix who have been invited back.
  2. Speed Demons (Blue / Black) - This is a crew led by Winter and The Speed Demon, they have a chance for freedom by Valgavoth if they manage to obtain the Aether Spark.
  3. The Endriders (Black / Red) - Survivors from Gastal, a harsh environment of natural disaster and road warriors (think Mad Max). Now at Ghurapur they're wanting to obtain the Aetherspark to bring it unlimited water.
  4. Goblin Rocketeers (Red / Green) - This team is rocket scientists who have applied their knowledge to cars and other vehicles. Their goal is to break the velocity limit to escape from their plane and worship the BOOSTGOD. (We were specifically told that that's in all capital letters)
  5. Alacrian Quickbeasts (Green / White) - These racers ride beasts instead of vehicles and are interested in the Grand Prix based purely out of their enjoyment of competition.
  6. The Champions of Amonkhet (White / Black) - A team of living and undead representatives from Amonkhet led by Basri and Zahur.
  7. The Speedbrood (Black / Green) - A group of insectoid racers who are trying to grow their life into becoming velocity and speed itself.
  8. Aether Rangers (Green / Blue) - The team native to Avashkar equipped with fast vehicles that slightly hover giving them an edge over any terrain.
  9. Chordatan Keelhaulers (Blue / Red) - Fishfolk who are new to the Grand Prix but who have settled in Avashkar.
  10. Cloudspire Racing Team (Red / White) - Racers from Kylum that specialize in high speed and low drag racing allowing them to be very quick. This team also won the previous year's Grand Prix.

Art Worth A Thousand Laps

Full Art Lands will show the different courses that the teams will be racing on from a first-person perspective of some of the drivers. You'll get to see sand-covered raceways, winding jungle tracks, and even scenes of vehicles racing down riverways.

Another new look for cards is the Borderless Revved Up treatment that each of the teams have. Each of these cards are meant to highlight a driver and their vehicle, working as a sort of glamour-shot showing off what is meant to be an inspirational scene.

Wassell likened these treatments to something you might see a full page ad for in a magazine, or the kind of poster that a fan of the team or driver would want.

Aetherdrift Commander Decks

There are two Commander Decks that will be released with Aetherdrift. One led by Temmet, Eternal Might, which will be a White/Blue/Black deck. This Commander Deck will not only have Temmet but also Hashaton, Scarab's Fist and will focus on creating zombies and building up to one big turn where you flood your enemy with damage.

The second Commander Deck is Living Energy, a Green/Blue/Red deck, that features Saheeli, Radiant Creator and Pia Nalaar, Chief Mechanic as Commanders.

Both of these Commander Decks will retail for $44.99 MSRP

First-place Foil Cards

Box-Toppers for this set will come with a new First-place Foil treatment. This version is meant to look like a gold prize medal and while the background and outer elements are shiny and gold the core element of the card's artwork and focus of the card will remain in color to really pop.

Magic The Gathering Aetherdrift Release Timing

For those wanting to keep an eye out for everything Magic The Gathering Aetherdrift, you can keep an eye out for the following dates.

  • Aetherdrift Story reveal (This is already out)
  • Debut and Previews Begin - January 21st
  • Pre-Release Events - February 7-13
  • MTG Arena Release - February 11th
  • Tabletop Release - February 14th

item.title: Indie Smash Hit Balatro Hits 5m Sales
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/balatro-sales-5m

Publisher PlayStack and developer LocalThunk have announced that smash hit indie card roguelike Balatro has passed yet another major sales milestone, further solidifying the game's status as a runaway success.

In a message on social media platform X, the two studios reveal that Balatro has crossed the five million sales mark, which puts it about on par with Nexon's "indie" hit Dave the Diver or Focus and Saber's Warhammer 40k: Space Marine 2.

The studios thank everyone who's played Balatro "after seeing it at The Game Awards", where it was nominated for (and eventually won) the Best Indie Game prize. Rather charmingly, the studios then recommend trying to make playing indie games "a habit", as "there's some amazing stuff out there".

It's been an excellent year for Balatro, all things considered. The game launched in February 2024 and quickly crossed the half-million sales mark, going on to break a million sales less than two weeks after that milestone.

In August last year, Balatro hit two million sales, and in December of the same year, Playstack and LocalThunk announced the game had reached 3.5 million, which means it's managed to rack up another 1.5 million in the intervening weeks.

If you've somehow managed to come this far without either playing or hearing about Balatro (and you're not alone if you're in the first camp, because I haven't either), it's a poker roguelike in which the goal is to rack up points by utilizing "adrenaline-pumping, outrageous combos".

While it bases itself on poker, Balatro's appeal lies in its array of powerful joker cards, which provide a range of bonuses. Stacking these bonuses up correctly is the key to building your score and breaking through to the next round.

You can check out Balatro right now on...well, on pretty much everything: PC, PlayStation, Xbox, Nintendo Switch, and mobile devices. Stay tuned for more.

item.title: Grimdark CRPG Warhammer 40k: Rogue Trader Hits a Million Sales
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/warhammer-40k-rogue-trader-1m-sales

Owlcat has announced that its grimdark CRPG Warhammer 40k: Rogue Trader has managed to hit a major sales milestone just over a year after the game's initial 1.0 release.

According to a press release, Rogue Trader has crossed one million sales across all of the platforms on which it's currently available, i.e. PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S.

Studio head Oleg Shpilchevskiy says the milestone is a "sign" that Owlcat is "working in the right direction", and that he wants his team to "bring more stories to the endless universe of Warhammer 40k".

If you're not familiar with Warhammer 40k: Rogue Trader, it's a CRPG set in the grim darkness of the Warhammer 40k universe. As the title suggests, you play one of the titular Rogue Traders, who are essentially Imperium-sanctioned explorers and merchants given special permission to travel the galaxy.

As you'd expect from an Owlcat game, you'll meet a number of companions who represent several of the Warhammer 40k setting's races and character archetypes. Companions include a Navis Nobilite navigator, a tech-priest, and a warrior from the Adeptus Sororitas, among many others.

Released in alpha in 2022, the game scored a full 1.0 release on PC and consoles in December 2023, and a number of updates both big and small have been released for Rogue Trader in the intervening months.

In September last year, Rogue Trader's first DLC, Void Shadows, was released. It added lots of content to the game, including a new Death Cult assassin companion, new quests, and more.

Another major expansion, Lex Imperialis, is currently in the works, bringing a new companion from the Adeptus Arbite, which you can essentially think of as the Imperium's police force. Naturally, you can also look forward to new areas, mechanics, and plenty more in that expansion.

You can grab Rogue Trader right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S.

item.title: DayZ Studio Bohemia Interactive Reports "Extremely Successful" 2024
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/bohemia-interactive-revenue-up-2024

DayZ and Arma studio Bohemia Interactive has reported an "extremely successful 2024", contrasting against what the Czech studio calls the "global stagnation" of the gaming industry at large.

In a press release, Bohemia says its revenue jumped 34% in 2024, reaching a total of $60.8 million. The company managed to sell 4.85 million copies of its games across PC and consoles last year, with player numbers hitting 17 million around the world.

According to Bohemia, 99% of those sales came from "abroad" rather than from its native Czech Republic, with the US enjoying a 42% market share. Bohemia also reports "significant growth" in Ukraine, which saw player numbers doubling year-on year, and points to Brazil as a market of "growing importance".

Bohemia co-founder Slavomír Pavlíček says 2024 "exceeded all our expectations" and that Arma Reforger, which launched on PS5 in December last year, "currently has no competition in its genre" on Sony's platform, which contributed to Bohemia's success.

The studio also says that fans can look forward to "interesting game surprises" over the coming year, including the "intensive development" of Arma 4, which is now expected to launch sometime in 2027.

More games under the Bohemia Incubator program, through which Bohemia gives smaller teams funding and publishing support for their games, will also be introduced this year, with action platformer Brute Horse and sandbox RPG SkyVerse both on Bohemia's 2024 infographic.

The "global stagnation" of which Bohemia speaks has seen a lot of game studios caught up in its field, with major studios like Microsoft, Sony, and Take-Two laying off staff members, shutting down studios, and even canceling live service games shortly after release in 2024.

It's fair to say that Bohemia's growth certainly goes against the grain in that regard, although given the eye-watering cash some of these companies' C-suites took home for themselves last year and the year before, I'd question whether those decisions were, in fact, made due to industry trends.

In any case, we'll bring you more on what Bohemia Interactive gets up to in 2025 as and when we get it, so stay tuned for that.
